title: Derivatives: Definition & Basic Rules
description: Students develop the formal definition of the derivative as the limit of the difference quotient, interpret the derivative as an instantaneous rate of change, and establish conditions for differentiability versus continuity. They then build a toolkit of basic differentiation rules — power, product, quotient, and sum/difference — along with common derivatives for trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions. The unit closes with reading and estimating derivatives from graphs and tables, a skill heavily tested on the AP exam. Weekly rhythm includes AP-style FRQ derivative problems.
goals: Compute derivatives using the limit definition (difference quotient) in both forms and interpret the result as the slope of the tangent line.
Interpret the derivative as an instantaneous rate of change in applied contexts with correct units.
Determine where a function is differentiable and explain the relationship between differentiability and continuity.
Apply the power rule, product rule, quotient rule, and sum/difference rules fluently.
Differentiate trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions from memory.
Estimate and interpret derivatives from graphs and tables of values.
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release: concept-intro → I Do → concept-check → We Do → check-in → You Do → mastery-check
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank; AI makes all instructional decisions
Start with the geometric meaning (tangent line slope) before the formal limit definition — build intuition first
Weekly AP-style FRQ derivative problems for exam preparation
Spiral prior: limit techniques and continuity from Unit 1 underpin the derivative definition

scaffold.title: The Derivative: Definition via Difference Quotient
scaffold.content: The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient. Geometrically, it is the slope of the tangent line at that point — the limit of secant line slopes as the two points merge. There are two standard forms, and students must be fluent with both.
keyPoints: Difference quotient (h-form): f'(a) = lim(h→0) [f(a+h) - f(a)] / h. This is the PRIMARY definition on the AP exam.
Difference quotient (x-form): f'(a) = lim(x→a) [f(x) - f(a)] / (x - a). Equivalent form — often seen on MC questions.
General derivative function: f'(x) = lim(h→0) [f(x+h) - f(x)] / h. Produces a NEW function giving slope at any x.
Geometric meaning: the derivative at x = a is the slope of the line tangent to y = f(x) at the point (a, f(a)).
Tangent line equation: y - f(a) = f'(a)(x - a). Point-slope form using the derivative as slope.
If the limit DNE, the derivative at that point does not exist (the function is not differentiable there).

examples.problem: Use the limit definition (h-form) to find f'(x) for f(x) = x² + 3x.
examples.solution: f'(x) = lim(h→0) [(x+h)² + 3(x+h) - (x² + 3x)] / h = lim(h→0) [x² + 2xh + h² + 3x + 3h - x² - 3x] / h = lim(h→0) [2xh + h² + 3h] / h = lim(h→0) (2x + h + 3) = 2x + 3.

examples.problem: Use the limit definition (x-form) to find f'(4) for f(x) = √x.
Find f'(x) using the definition for f(x) = 1/x, then write the equation of the tangent line at x = 2.
The definition of the derivative of g at x = 5 is given as lim(h→0) [(5+h)³ - 125] / h. Identify the function g and find this limit.
examples.solution: Compare with lim(h→0) [g(5+h) - g(5)] / h. So g(x) = x³ and g(5) = 125. We need g'(5). Using the definition: expand (5+h)³ = 125 + 75h + 15h² + h³. So [125 + 75h + 15h² + h³ - 125] / h = 75 + 15h + h². As h→0: g'(5) = 75.

scaffold.title: The Derivative as Rate of Change
scaffold.content: The derivative is the instantaneous rate of change of f with respect to x. It generalizes the concept of velocity, growth rate, and marginal cost. Units of the derivative are always (units of output) / (units of input). AP FRQs test interpretation heavily.
keyPoints: Average rate of change on [a, b] = [f(b) - f(a)] / (b - a) = slope of secant line.
Instantaneous rate of change at x = a = f'(a) = slope of tangent line = limit of average rates.
If s(t) is position, then s'(t) is velocity and s''(t) is acceleration.
Units of f'(x): (units of f) per (unit of x). Example: if P(t) = population and t = years, then P'(t) is people per year.
AP interpretation format: 'At t = 3, the [quantity] is [increasing/decreasing] at a rate of |f'(3)| [units] per [unit of input].'
f'(a) > 0 means f is increasing at x = a. f'(a) < 0 means f is decreasing at x = a. f'(a) = 0 means horizontal tangent.

scaffold.title: Derivative as Rate of Change — Worked Examples

examples.problem: A particle moves along the x-axis with position s(t) = t³ - 6t² + 9t + 2 (feet, seconds). Find the velocity at t = 1 and interpret.
examples.solution: v(t) = s'(t) = 3t² - 12t + 9. v(1) = 3 - 12 + 9 = 0 ft/sec. Interpretation: At t = 1 second, the particle's velocity is 0 ft/sec — it is momentarily at rest (changing direction).

examples.problem: The cost to produce x widgets is C(x) = 500 + 8x - 0.02x² dollars. Find and interpret C'(100).
examples.solution: C'(x) = 8 - 0.04x. C'(100) = 8 - 4 = 4. Interpretation: When 100 widgets are being produced, the cost is increasing at a rate of $4 per additional widget. This is the marginal cost of the 101st widget.

examples.problem: Water drains from a tank. The volume V(t) (gallons) at time t (minutes) satisfies V(3) = 50 and V'(3) = -8. Interpret V'(3) in context.
examples.solution: At t = 3 minutes, the volume of water in the tank is decreasing at a rate of 8 gallons per minute. The tank contains 50 gallons at that moment and is losing water at 8 gal/min.

scaffold.title: Differentiability vs. Continuity
scaffold.content: Differentiability is a stronger condition than continuity. If f is differentiable at a, then f is continuous at a — but NOT vice versa. Knowing where and why derivatives fail to exist is a key AP skill.
keyPoints: Theorem: Differentiable at a ⟹ Continuous at a. The converse is FALSE.
If f is NOT continuous at a, then f is NOT differentiable at a. (Contrapositive of the theorem.)
Corner: left and right derivatives exist but are different. Example: f(x) = |x| at x = 0. Left derivative = -1, right derivative = +1.
Cusp: derivatives from both sides go to ±∞ in opposite directions. Example: f(x) = x^(2/3) at x = 0.
Vertical tangent: derivative goes to +∞ or -∞ from both sides (same sign). Example: f(x) = x^(1/3) at x = 0.
Discontinuity: any type (removable, jump, infinite) automatically means not differentiable at that point.

examples.problem: Show that f(x) = |x - 3| is continuous but not differentiable at x = 3.
examples.solution: Continuity: lim(x→3) |x-3| = 0 = f(3). Continuous. Differentiability: Rewrite f(x) = {x-3, x ≥ 3; -(x-3), x < 3}. Left derivative: lim(h→0⁻) [|3+h-3| - 0]/h = lim(h→0⁻) (-h)/h = -1. Right derivative: lim(h→0⁺) h/h = 1. Left ≠ right, so f'(3) DNE. Corner at x = 3.

examples.problem: Determine if f(x) = x^(2/3) is differentiable at x = 0.
examples.solution: f(0) = 0. f'(0) = lim(h→0) h^(2/3)/h = lim(h→0) h^(-1/3) = lim(h→0) 1/h^(1/3). From the right: 1/h^(1/3) → +∞. From the left: 1/(-|h|)^(1/3) → -∞. The one-sided limits are +∞ and -∞ (opposite signs) — this is a cusp. Not differentiable at x = 0.

examples.problem: For f(x) = {x², x ≤ 1; 2x - 1, x > 1}, determine if f is differentiable at x = 1.
examples.solution: Check continuity first: lim(x→1⁻) x² = 1. lim(x→1⁺) (2x-1) = 1. f(1) = 1. Continuous. Left derivative: d/dx(x²) at x=1 = 2(1) = 2. Right derivative: d/dx(2x-1) at x=1 = 2. Left = right = 2, so f'(1) = 2. Differentiable at x = 1.

examples.problem: If g is differentiable at x = 5, what can you conclude about continuity? If g is continuous at x = 5, can you conclude differentiability?
examples.solution: Since g is differentiable at x = 5, g MUST be continuous at x = 5 (differentiability implies continuity). However, if g is only continuous at x = 5, you CANNOT conclude differentiability. Counterexample: g(x) = |x - 5| is continuous at x = 5 but has a corner there.

scaffold.title: Basic Differentiation Rules
scaffold.content: Once the derivative is defined, we build shortcuts so we don't need the limit definition every time. The power rule, product rule, quotient rule, and sum/difference rules form the core toolkit for differentiation.
keyPoints: Constant rule: d/dx[c] = 0. The derivative of any constant is zero.
Constant multiple rule: d/dx[c·f(x)] = c·f'(x). Constants pull out of derivatives.
Power rule: d/dx[xⁿ] = n·xⁿ⁻¹. Works for ALL real n — integers, fractions, negatives.
Sum/Difference rule: d/dx[f ± g] = f' ± g'. Differentiate term by term.
Product rule: d/dx[f·g] = f'·g + f·g'. Order: (derivative of first)(second) + (first)(derivative of second).
Quotient rule: d/dx[f/g] = [f'·g - f·g'] / g². Mnemonic: 'lo d-hi minus hi d-lo over lo-lo.'
Rewrite before differentiating: convert radicals and fractions to power form (e.g., √x = x^(1/2), 1/x² = x⁻²) to use the power rule instead of the quotient rule when possible.

examples.problem: Differentiate: f(x) = 4x⁵ - 3x³ + 7x - 2.
examples.solution: Apply power rule term by term: f'(x) = 4·5x⁴ - 3·3x² + 7·1 - 0 = 20x⁴ - 9x² + 7.

examples.problem: Differentiate: g(x) = (3x² + 1)(x⁴ - 2x).
examples.solution: Product rule: g'(x) = (6x)(x⁴ - 2x) + (3x² + 1)(4x³ - 2). Expand: 6x⁵ - 12x² + 12x⁵ - 6x² + 4x³ - 2 = 18x⁵ + 4x³ - 18x² - 2. (Or expand first: 3x⁶ + x⁴ - 6x³ - 2x, then differentiate: 18x⁵ + 4x³ - 18x² - 2.)

examples.problem: Differentiate: h(x) = (2x + 5)/(x² - 1).
examples.solution: Quotient rule: h'(x) = [2(x² - 1) - (2x + 5)(2x)] / (x² - 1)². Numerator: 2x² - 2 - 4x² - 10x = -2x² - 10x - 2. So h'(x) = (-2x² - 10x - 2)/(x² - 1)² = -2(x² + 5x + 1)/(x² - 1)².

examples.problem: Differentiate by rewriting first: f(x) = (3/x²) + 5√x - 4/∛x.

scaffold.title: Common Derivatives: Trig, Exponential & Logarithmic
scaffold.content: Beyond the power rule, certain function families have derivatives that must be memorized. These are used constantly in AP Calculus and form the building blocks for the chain rule in Unit 3.
keyPoints: d/dx[sin x] = cos x. d/dx[cos x] = -sin x. (Note the negative on cosine!)
d/dx[tan x] = sec²x. d/dx[cot x] = -csc²x.
d/dx[sec x] = sec x · tan x. d/dx[csc x] = -csc x · cot x. (Cofunctions get the negative.)
d/dx[eˣ] = eˣ. The exponential function is its own derivative — the defining property of e.
d/dx[ln x] = 1/x (x > 0). d/dx[ln|x|] = 1/x (x ≠ 0).
d/dx[aˣ] = aˣ · ln a. d/dx[log_a(x)] = 1/(x · ln a).
These combine with product/quotient rules immediately. Chain rule (Unit 3) extends them to compositions.

examples.problem: Differentiate: f(x) = 3sin x - 2cos x + eˣ.
examples.solution: f'(x) = 3cos x - 2(-sin x) + eˣ = 3cos x + 2sin x + eˣ. Key: the derivative of cos x is NEGATIVE sin x, so the double negative produces +2sin x.

examples.problem: Differentiate: g(x) = x² · tan x.
examples.solution: Product rule: g'(x) = 2x · tan x + x² · sec²x. No further simplification needed unless a specific form is requested.

examples.problem: Differentiate: h(x) = eˣ / (x + 1).
examples.solution: Quotient rule: h'(x) = [eˣ(x + 1) - eˣ(1)] / (x + 1)² = eˣ(x + 1 - 1) / (x + 1)² = x·eˣ / (x + 1)².

examples.problem: Differentiate: y = 5·2ˣ + 4ln x - sec x.
examples.solution: y' = 5·2ˣ·ln 2 + 4/x - sec x · tan x. Each term uses a memorized derivative: d/dx[aˣ] = aˣ ln a, d/dx[ln x] = 1/x, d/dx[sec x] = sec x tan x.

scaffold.title: Derivatives Practice: Definition, Rules & Common Functions

problems.problem: Use the limit definition to find f'(x) for f(x) = 3x² - x + 4.
hints: Subtract f(x), divide by h, take the limit
problems.answer: f(x+h) - f(x) = 6xh + 3h² - h. Divide by h: 6x + 3h - 1. As h→0: f'(x) = 6x - 1.

problems.problem: For f(x) = {2x², x ≤ 1; 4x - 2, x > 1}, determine if f is differentiable at x = 1.
hints: First check continuity: do both pieces give the same value at x = 1?
Find the derivative of each piece at x = 1
problems.answer: Continuity: lim(x→1⁻) 2(1)² = 2. lim(x→1⁺) 4(1)-2 = 2. f(1) = 2. Continuous. Left derivative: d/dx(2x²) at x=1 = 4(1) = 4. Right derivative: d/dx(4x-2) = 4. Left = right = 4. Differentiable, f'(1) = 4.
Quotient rule: y' = [(3x² + 2)sin x - (x³ + 2x)cos x] / sin²x.

problems.problem: A company's revenue is R(t) = 120t - 3t² thousand dollars, where t is months after launch. Find and interpret R'(10).
hints: State units and direction of change
problems.answer: R'(t) = 120 - 6t. R'(10) = 120 - 60 = 60. At t = 10 months, revenue is increasing at a rate of $60 thousand per month.

scaffold.title: Derivatives from Graphs & Tables
scaffold.content: On the AP exam, students frequently need to estimate derivatives from data tables (using the difference quotient) and to read derivative values from graphs of f (slope of the curve). They also must connect the graph of f to the behavior of f'.
keyPoints: From a table: approximate f'(a) ≈ [f(a+h) - f(a-h)] / (2h) using the symmetric difference quotient (best approximation with equal spacing).
One-sided approximation: f'(a) ≈ [f(a+h) - f(a)] / h or [f(a) - f(a-h)] / h when data is only available on one side.
From a graph of f: f'(a) = slope of the tangent line at x = a. Estimate visually by drawing the tangent and computing rise/run.
f' > 0 where f is increasing. f' < 0 where f is decreasing. f' = 0 at local maxima/minima and horizontal tangents.
f' is undefined at corners, cusps, vertical tangents, and discontinuities of f.
Steeper graph of f means |f'| is larger. Flat portions of f mean f' ≈ 0.

scaffold.title: Derivatives from Graphs & Tables — Worked Examples

examples.problem: The table gives: t = 0, 2, 4, 6, 8 with f(t) = 10, 18, 24, 28, 30. Estimate f'(4).
examples.solution: Use the symmetric difference quotient: f'(4) ≈ [f(6) - f(2)] / (6 - 2) = (28 - 18) / 4 = 10/4 = 2.5. This averages the forward and backward slopes for the best estimate at the interior point.

examples.problem: From a graph of f, the tangent line at x = 3 appears to pass through (1, 2) and (5, 10). Estimate f'(3).
examples.solution: f'(3) = slope of tangent line = (10 - 2)/(5 - 1) = 8/4 = 2. The derivative at x = 3 is approximately 2.

examples.problem: A graph of f shows: f increases on (0, 2), has a horizontal tangent at x = 2, decreases on (2, 5), has a corner at x = 5, and increases on (5, 7). Describe f'.
examples.solution: f' > 0 on (0, 2). f'(2) = 0 (horizontal tangent — local max). f' < 0 on (2, 5). f'(5) is undefined (corner). f' > 0 on (5, 7). The graph of f' would be positive, cross zero at x = 2, go negative, have a break at x = 5, then jump positive.

scaffold.title: Derivatives: Definition & Basic Rules Mastery Practice

problems.problem: Use the limit definition to find f'(x) for f(x) = 1/(2x + 1).

problems.answer: Product rule on first term: g'(x) = 4x³·cos x + x⁴·(-sin x) + 3eˣ = 4x³cos x - x⁴sin x + 3eˣ.

problems.problem: For f(x) = {x³, x ≤ 0; x², x > 0}, is f differentiable at x = 0? Justify completely.
problems.answer: Continuity: lim(x→0⁻) 0³ = 0, lim(x→0⁺) 0² = 0, f(0) = 0. Continuous. Left derivative: d/dx(x³) at 0 = 3(0)² = 0. Right derivative: d/dx(x²) at 0 = 2(0) = 0. Left = right = 0. Differentiable, f'(0) = 0.
Quotient rule: y' = [(cos x + eˣ)(x² + 1) - (sin x + eˣ)(2x)] / (x² + 1)².

problems.problem: The population of a city (thousands) is given in a table: t (years since 2000) = 0, 5, 10, 15, 20 with P(t) = 85, 102, 126, 143, 155. Estimate P'(10) and interpret in context.
problems.answer: P'(10) ≈ [P(15) - P(5)] / (15 - 5) = (143 - 102)/10 = 4.1 thousand people per year. At the year 2010, the city's population was increasing at approximately 4,100 people per year.

problems.problem: A graph of a function f is described: f passes through (0, 1), increases steeply to (1, 4) with slope ≈ 4, levels off with a horizontal tangent at (2, 5), then decreases through (3, 3) with slope ≈ -3, and has a corner at x = 4. State: (a) f'(0), (b) f'(2), (c) f'(3), (d) f'(4).
problems.answer: (a) f'(0): the graph increases through (0,1); estimate from the described steepness — f'(0) ≈ 2 (initial slope before the steep part). (b) f'(2) = 0 (horizontal tangent). (c) f'(3) ≈ -3 (slope of tangent at that point, given as ≈ -3). (d) f'(4) does not exist (corner).

answerKeys.diff-abs-value: Continuous at x=3, corner → not differentiable.
answerKeys.diff-piecewise-match: Continuous and differentiable at x=1. f'(1) = 2.
answerKeys.diff-theorem: Diff ⟹ Cont. Cont does NOT ⟹ Diff.
answerKeys.wp-diff-piecewise: Continuous and differentiable at x=1. f'(1) = 4.
answerKeys.ip-diff-piecewise: Continuous and differentiable at x=0. f'(0) = 0.
answerKeys.ip-table-population: P'(10) ≈ 4.1 thousand/year. Increasing at ~4,100 people/year in 2010.
